content.text: Does logic reflect the structure of reality, or just the structure of our language and thought? **Logical atomism** (Russell, early Wittgenstein) held that the world has a logical structure that our language mirrors.

content.definition: The view that reality consists of simple, independent 'atomic facts' that combine like logical propositions. A perfect language would have its structure match the world's structure.

content.text: On this view, logical connectives (and, or, not) reflect real relations in the world. When we say 'A and B,' there's a complex fact in reality combining the facts A and B.

content.title: Logical Form and Reality
premises: 'The cat is on the mat' has logical form: On(cat, mat)
This form reflects a real relation in the world
Predicates like 'On' correspond to real properties/relations
Names like 'cat' refer to real objects
content.note: Logical atomists believed language, properly analyzed, mirrors metaphysical structure.

content.text: Critics question whether reality has 'logical joints' — maybe we impose logical structure through language, rather than discovering it. The later Wittgenstein rejected his earlier atomism.
The debate continues: are predicates like 'red' natural kinds in reality, or arbitrary ways we've carved up experience? Does the world have a unique correct logical description?

content.question: What did logical atomism claim about logic and reality?
options: Logic reflects the structure of reality
content.explanation: Logical atomists (Russell, early Wittgenstein) believed that a properly analyzed language would mirror the logical structure of reality itself.
